Campus restrictions through the years

New York City ceded the rights to 116th Street between Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue to Columbia for the University’s “bicentennial beautification plans” and closed the street to vehicular traffic.

April 1953

Columbia officially renamed 116th Street between Broadway and Amsterdam to College Walk.

June 1955

Columbia received donations to install two “ornamental gates” to adorn the Broadway and Amsterdam entrances in July. By December, Columbia had installed the Broadway gates, which

were kept open to permit free campus access.

During the 1968 student protests against the Vietnam War and Columbia’s controversial plans to build a gymnasium in Morningside Park, Columbia restricted access to campus. The University barred 30 students, faculty, and community residents from campus after they failed to present Columbia IDs.

July 1967

May 1968

Following the Sept. 11 attacks on the World Trade Center, Columbia took preventative security measures, closed several gates, prohibited parking on College Walk, and increased security presence.

September 2001

Before planned demonstrations, Columbia restricted access to CUID holders. The University closed almost all campus gates for the first time in over 50 years.

October 2023

Following the occupation of Hamilton Hall, Morningside campus access was indefinitely restricted to essential personnel and students living in on-campus residence halls. This was one of the tightest restrictions Columbia has ever implemented.

April 2024

Beginning June 17, non-CUID holders were able to access campus from 7 a.m. to 5 p.m. throughout the summer. In August, Columbia restricted access again to only CUID holders in preparation for the academic year.

August 2024

Present Day

Campus access remains restricted to CUID holders.

Source: Spectator Reporting

Graphic by Nathan Shurts
